para.dtcname: Turbocharger Oil Leak and White Smoke

entry.ptxt: Oil leak from center housing to compressor housing (intake side) or turbine housing (exhaust side) through piston rings (seal rings).
Internal oil leak is not visible from outside of turbocharger.
If oil leak occurs from turbine side seal, large amount of white smoke will be emitted from exhaust pipe.

item.ptxt: Compressor side piston ring
Turbine side piston ring
Clogging of oil drain
Shaft breakage
Shaft and bearing seizure
Compressor wheel damage
Low quality fuel

entry.ptxt: Oil leak from inside of turbocharger to outside of turbocharger (e.g. from compressor housing , oil pipe flange or oil pipe union).
Includes oil leak visible from outside of turbocharger.

item.ptxt: Compressor housing
Oil pipe flange
Oil pipe union
Hose connection of intake pipe
Turbocharger oil leaks are classified into 2 types. One is an internal oil leak, and the other is an external oil leak.
When oil leaks and smoke occur, sometimes the turbocharger is mistakenly replaced, even though the turbocharger is not the cause of the problem.
When there are oil marks on the surface of the compressor housing, or oil in the compressor inlet or outlet, the problem may mistakenly be determined to be a turbocharger oil leak.
Each part of the turbocharger is shown below.

entry.ptxt: Internal oil leak to compressor housing
Internal oil leak to turbine housing

item.ptxt: Above illustration is an example.

If the oil stain is similar to the one shown in the illustration (fig. 1), it may be oil spray from parts surrounding the turbocharger or oil leaking from the air cleaner hose. Therefore, this kind of oil stain on the outer surface of the turbocharger is not an oil leak from the turbocharger (external oil leak), and is not related to white smoke. For identification of an actual turbocharger outer oil leak, check only the sealing part shown below.

entry.ptxt: Oil existence at compressor inlet (Max. 5 cm3)

item.ptxt: Above illustration is an example.

A certain amount of oil is contained in the intake system because blow-by gas containing oil mist is returned to the intake system by the PCV. Therefore, the oil amount at the compressor inlet shown in the left figure (fig. 2) is normal and not an oil leak from the turbocharger (internal oil leak). Also, oil at the compressor outlet as shown in fig. 3 is normal.
In addition, the compressor wheel surface may blacken due to blow-by gas but this is not abnormal.

entry.ptxt: In the case of an actual oil leak, oil leaks from the sealed part

item.ptxt: Above illustration is an example.
This is an illustration (fig. 4) of an air leak test performed by applying soapy water to the area of the leak. Bubbles indicate the leak point.

step1.ptxt: Faults and Symptoms of Turbocharger Parts

item.ptxt: Oil leak to compressor housing
Excessive oil consumption

In case of compressor piston ring failure, large amount of oil would be found between compressor outlet and intercooler, and between intercooler and intake manifold, but not found at compressor inlet.
If large amount of oil is found at compressor inlet, it is not from turbocharger and may indicate a problem in the PCV system.
Oil leak to turbine housing
Large amount of white smoke from exhaust pipe
Excessive oil consumption
In case of turbine piston ring failure, large amount of white smoke would be emitted continuously.

If white smoke is emitted only just after engine start (and it disappears later), or small amount of white smoke is emitted intermittently, it is not from turbocharger. It is due to failure of other parts.
If wet oil is found at turbine inlet, it is not from turbocharger. It is due to problem in other parts.

entry.ptxt: Oil drain clogging by coked oil
Large amount of white smoke from exhaust pipe

item.ptxt: Oil coking is caused by insufficient oil maintenance.

If the oil drain is clogged by coked oil, oil cannot be drained smoothly, and it overflows from the center housing to the compressor housing and turbine housing. This results in a large amount of white smoke from the exhaust pipe.
If any solid (coked oil) is visually confirmed inside the center housing, it can be assumed to be the cause of internal oil leak.

entry.ptxt: Oil drain clogged with coked oil

item.ptxt: Breakage
Seizure
Shaft does not rotate
Oil leak to compressor housing
Large amount of white smoke from exhaust pipe
Lack of power
Turbocharger noise changes
In case of turbine shaft failure, lack of power due to lack of boost pressure will be felt.
In cold conditions, shaft rotation can feel somewhat clingy due to viscosity of oil. Be sure not to mistake it for unsmooth shaft rotation.
Shaft does not rotate
Oil leak to compressor housing
Lack of power
In case of compressor wheel failure, large amount of oil would be found between compressor outlet and intercooler, and between intercooler and intake manifold, but not found at compressor inlet.
Oil is blocked by boost pressure at compressor piston ring (seal ring). Therefore, if boost pressure does not increase due to breakage of compressor wheel, oil flows out to compressor housing.

entry.ptxt: Oil leak from FIPG sealing part

item.ptxt: If oil stain is separated from FIPG sealing part, it can be determined to be due to oil spray from otherparts surrounding turbocharger.
If oil stain is traced to hose connection part, it can be determined to be due to hose connection failure.

entry.ptxt: Oil Leak from FIPG Sealing Part
Oil leak from hose connection between hose and compressor housing
If oil stain is traced to hose connection part, it can be determined to be due to hose connection failure.
Trace of oil leak from hose connection part
Oil leak from hose connection part

test1.ptxt: Check whether the oil leak is an internal or external oil leak.

atten4.ptxt: White smoke is not related to an external oil leak.

entry.ptxt: Oil leak from center housing to compressor housing (intake side) or turbine housing (exhaust side) through piston rings (seal rings).
Internal oil leak is not visible from outside of turbocharger.
If oil leak occurs from turbine side seal, large amount of white smoke will be emitted from exhaust pipe.
Oil leak from inside of turbocharger to outside of turbocharger (e.g. from FIPG seal, oil pipe flange or oil pipe union).
Includes oil leaks visible from outside of turbocharger.

testgrp.testtitle: REPLACE THE PART WHICH IS LEAKING OIL

test1.ptxt: Replace the part which is leaking oil.

testgrp.testtitle: CHECK WHETHER WHITE SMOKE IS EMITTED

test1.ptxt: Fully depress the accelerator pedal, and then release it.
Check whether white smoke is emitted or not when racing the engine.

atten3.ptxt: Be sure not to check for white smoke indoors.

item.ptxt: If white smoke appears for only a short period of time immediately after the engine is started, the white smoke is not from the turbocharger.

If the turbocharger is the cause of the problem, regardless of whether the engine is cold or warmed up, there will be a large amount of white smoke to the extent that visibility is obstructed for a few meters in the area of the smoke (as shown in the illustration).
Depending on whether there is oil mixed with the fuel, or whether there is unburned fuel present, the smell of the exhaust gas differs. When oil is mixed in, the exhaust gas smells like burning oil.

test1.ptxt: Connect the DTC to the DLC3.
Turn the ignition switch to ON and turn the GTS on.
Enter the following menus: Powertrain / Engine and ECT / Trouble Codes.

gts-info.title: Powertrain > Engine and ECT > Trouble Codes

test1.ptxt: Read DTCs.

entry.ptxt: DTCs related to engine are output

testgrp.testtitle: CHECK WHITE SMOKE (ACCORDING TO ENGINE CONDITION)

test1.ptxt: Check whether the white smoke is emitted only just after engine start and disappears later, or not.

item.ptxt: If white smoke appears for only a short period of time immediately after the engine is started, the white smoke is not from the turbocharger.

If the turbocharger is the cause of the problem, regardless of whether the engine is cold or warmed up, there will be a large amount of white smoke to the extent that visibility is obstructed for a few meters in the area of the smoke (as shown in the illustration).
Depending on whether there is oil mixed with the fuel, or whether there is unburned fuel present, the smell of the exhaust gas differs. When oil is mixed in, the exhaust gas smells like burning oil.

entry.ptxt: Yes (white smoke is emitted only just after engine start)
No (white smoke is always and continuously emitted)

testgrp.testtitle: CHECK TEMPERATURE WHEN WHITE SMOKE IS EMITTED

test1.ptxt: Check whether the white smoke is emitted only in cold weather when the temperature is less than 0°C (32°F).

item.ptxt: If the white smoke is emitted only in cold conditions, the smoke is not from the turbocharger and may be the smoke of unburned fuel.
If misfiring occurs, unburned fuel is emitted.

entry.ptxt: Yes (white smoke is emitted in only cold conditions)
No (white smoke is emitted in both cold and warm conditions)

test1.ptxt: Inspect the glow plug assembly.
Click here
Read the injector compensation codes.
Click here

specitem.ptxt: Compensation codes stored in the ECM match compensation codes of the installed fuel injectors.

atten4.ptxt: If those do not match, register correct compensation code.

test1.ptxt: Check the fuel system.
Click here
Check the cylinder compression pressure.
Click here

item.ptxt: Active Test function "Check the Cylinder Compression" helps determine whether a cylinder has compression loss or not.

test2.ptxt: Connect the GTS to the DLC3.
Turn the ignition switch to ON and turn the GTS on.
Enter the following menus: Powertrain / Engine and ECT / Active Test / Check the Cylinder Compression / Data List / Compression / Engine Speed of Cyl #1 to #8.

gts-info.title: Powertrain > Engine and ECT > Active Test

test2.ptxt: Press the RIGHT or LEFT button to change the Check the Cylinder Compression to ON.
Crank the engine until the monitor item values Engine speed of Cyl #1 to #8 and Av Engine Speed of All Cyl change.

specitem.ptxt: The values of Engine Speed Cyl #1 to #8 are within +/-10 rpm of each other.

test2.ptxt: When cranking, if the speed of a cylinder is approximately 100 rpm more than the other cylinders, there is probably a complete loss of compression in that cylinder.

item.ptxt: If any of following malfunctions occurs, white smoke is emitted.
(a) Nozzle seat sealing failure
(b) Piston cracking
(c) Piston rings breakage

To check whether the pistons and piston rings have a malfunction, remove the oil level dipstick. If oil sprays out, the pressure inside the crankcase has risen which indicates that there is a malfunction in a piston or piston ring.

action.actiontitle: CHECK ENGINE TO DETERMINE CAUSE OF LOW COMPRESSION

test1.ptxt: Replace the turbocharger sub-assembly.
Click here

testgrp.testtitle: CONFIRM WHETHER MALFUNCTION HAS BEEN SUCCESSFULLY REPAIRED

test1.ptxt: Check whether the white smoke problem has been successfully repaired by starting the engine.
Remove the intake air connector pipe and the inlet compressor elbow.
Check whether an excessive amount of oil is present or not, and whether excessive oil deposits are attached to the compressor wheel or not.

item.ptxt: A certain amount of oil may be present as shown in fig. 2 in "Description", because a certain amount of oil mist is contained in the PCV gas and this oil accumulates just before the compressor inlet.
If an excessive amount of oil is present at the compressor inlet, there may be a problem in the PCV system.

test1.ptxt: Reinstall the intake air connector pipe and the inlet compressor elbow.
Remove the air tube from the compressor outlet.
Check whether or not an excessive amount of oil or excessive oil deposits are present at the compressor outlet.

atten4.ptxt: A certain amount of oil may be present as shown in fig. 3 in "Description", because a certain amount of oil mist is contained in the PCV gas.

entry.ptxt: Excessive amount of oil present at both compressor inlet and outlet
Excessive amount of oil present only at compressor outlet
Excessive amount of oil not present at compressor inlet and outlet

test1.ptxt: Reinstall the air hose.
Remove the monolithic converter assembly.
Check whether an excessive amount of wet oil or excessive oil deposits are present at the turbine outlet.

atten4.ptxt: Be sure not to mistake carbon soot for oil.

test1.ptxt: Remove the turbocharger from the engine.
Click here
Check whether an excessive amount of wet oil or excessive oil deposits are present at the turbine inlet.

item.ptxt: Be sure not to mistake carbon soot for oil.

If the turbocharger shaft is tilted, some amount of oil will flow out from the bearing housing. Therefore, be sure not to mistake oil that flowed out from the bearing housing during or after the removal of the turbocharger for oil that was present before the removal of the turbocharger.
If an excessive amount of oil or excessive oil deposits are present at the turbine inlet, this oil is coming from the exhaust port of the cylinders, and may indicate a problem in 1 or more cylinders.

entry.ptxt: Excessive amount of oil present at both turbine inlet and outlet
Excessive amount of oil present only at turbine outlet

action.actiontitle: CHECK ENGINE TO DETERMINE CAUSE OF OIL IN TURBOCHARGER

test1.ptxt: Replace the turbocharger sub-assembly.
Click here

testgrp.testtitle: CONFIRM WHETHER MALFUNCTION HAS BEEN SUCCESSFULLY REPAIRED

test1.ptxt: Check whether the oil leakage problem has been successfully repaired.
